Tympanic membrane perforations may occur as the result of a pressure wave in the external ear canal, or by direct penetration. About 50% are attributable to slap injuries or direct blows. Other reasons may be self-inflicted penetrating injuries account for about 25%. In the cases of traumatic perforation patient suffers with pain, reversible conductive deafness, may complicated with tinnitus and vertigo. Large studies have shown that the mean time for spontaneous healing is about 1.5 month and majority will have healed within 3 months. ). No wet mount examination or other serologic/PCR tests were performed. The patient was started on empiric antibiotic and antiviral therapy for suspected meningitis.

). However, the patient expired few minutes after the results were called. A CT scan of the head before death revealed cerebral edema. The diagnosis of amebic meningoencephalitis was later confirmed from the stained CSF slide by the Center for Disease Control and Prevention.
The infection is transmitted through swimming and diving and has been reported to occur with the use of nasal pots.

The organism enters the body through the nose crossing the cribriform plate to reach the brain. After a short incubation period of 2-3 days, the rapidly progressive disease causes severe hemorrhagic necrosis of the olfactory bulb. The diagnosis of PAM is suspected from the characteristic history and from finding of high protein and neutrophils counts in the CSF with low or normal glucose levels.

A wet mount may reveal its characteristic movement using phase contrast microscopy. Lack of eosinophilia helps to exclude more common causes of parasitic meningoencephalitis. In this case, the organism’s morphology reflected some degree of degeneration with cytoplasmic vacuoles, pale staining, and indistinct nucleolus. However, the organism’s overall size and irregular shape with small central nucleus was diagnostic (
). The presence of amoeba may be confirmed with immunofluorescence, enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA), or reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction.
The disease is almost always fatal and only very few patients out of more than 200 reported cases have survived.
Surviving patients were treated early with amphotericin B in various combinations with azithromycin, rifampin, fluconazole or miconazole.
These anti-infectives may have mild amebicidal activity but exhibit a considerable synergistic effect when given in combination.

The rapid progression of symptoms and signs of meningoencephalitis in a patient with history of swimming in fresh water may lead to early suspicion and prompt attainment of a diagnostic CSF specimen. In this case, there was undue delay in the management, as the diagnosis was not suspected despite suggestive clinical presentation and social history, a lumbar puncture was not performed early at initial presentation in the ER, and the fact that it took the pathologist more than six hours to stain, review and relay the CSF cytology results. Thus, early suspicion, accurate and rapid diagnosis through CSF cytology and prompt treatment are essential for patient’s survival and prevention of

TheraCal PT is a newer dual-cured resin-modified calcium silicate material with comparable biological properties to Biodentine. However, its bond strength to the dentin substrate is not known, especially for its use in Primary teeth. Hence, the current study aimed to evaluate and compare the shear bond strength of two pulp capping materials, Biodentine and TheraCal PT in primary molars.

In this experimental study, twenty-eight non-carious primary molars which were nearing exfoliation, retained or for orthodontic purposes were extracted and collected. Using simple random sampling, they were randomly allocated into two groups with n= 14 in each group. Following occlusal flattening, cylindrical plastic tubes were stabilized and filled with TheraCal PT in group A and Biodentine in group B. All samples were incubated, subjected to Universal Testing Machine and analyzed under stereomicroscope for assessing the modes of failure.

Significant differences in modes of failure were observed between TheraCal PT and Biodentine groups with p=0.041. The modes of failure observed were mostly adhesive in group A compared to group B. The mean values of shear bond strength observed for groups A and B were 5.1±3.5 MPa and 3.1±1.2 MPa respectively.
Thus, the shear bond strength observed for TheraCal PT was found to be comparable to that of Biodentine in primary molars.
Indirect pulp therapy entails removing carious dentin that is infected while allowing the affected hard dental tissues to remineralize by placing a suitable biocompatible substance.
The materials used for pulp capping must be stable under dislodging forces due to pressure from application of restorative materials over it or chewing forces.
In order to ensure a suitable seal and prevent clinical failure, an adequate bond strength between the pulp capping agent and dentin surface is essential.

Calcium Hydroxide (CH), a traditional material for pulp capping in primary molars, has some drawbacks, including high dissolution, low compressive strength, and tunnel defect formation in dentin bridges that can result in void formation and microleakage.
Several calcium silicate and light cure calcium hydroxide based compounds were designed to address these problems. Due to its similar mechanical properties to dentin, Biodentine
To overcome the drawbacks of Biodentine
It is a dual cure material based on calcium silicate with a shorter setting time and can be placed directly into a prepared tooth and light cured.
By producing an alkaline pH, it enables calcium release and enhances pulp vitality.
Unfortunately, there is a paucity of information about this material’s mechanical characteristics like shear bond strength to dentinal surface.
with significance level α=0.05& σ=1.151, the sample size is calculated to n=14x2=28 using the formul
distilled water could be used as an optimum storage media for preserving extracted teeth before shear bond strength testing and hence, it is used in this study.

The specimens were stored in an incubator at 37 °C with 100% humidity for 48 hours to aid in the setting of the materials, prevent dehydration, and allow the development of their perfect physical characteristics.
Bond strength is defined as the interfacial adhesion between the substrate and the bonded material mediated by an adhesive layer.
Shear Bond Strength (SBS) measures a material’s resistance to forces that cause a failure parallel to the force’s direction.

In cases of inadequate adhesion and poor adaptation of pulp capping materials to deep dentin, there are risks of micro gap creation which would lead to fluctuation in dentinal fluids thus producing post-operative sensitivity and pain.
In the present study, no significant difference in shear bond strength was observed between TheraCal PT

Several factors like low initial bulk strength, mechanism of adhesion, quality of dentin and different particle sizes could be responsible for the differences in bond strength observed between both materials in this study. TheraCal LC achieved sufficient initial bulk strength on curing when used as a liner and the harmful effects of contraction stresses are very less while curing the overlying composite which could attribute to its higher shear bond strength.
Contrarily, Biodentine requires 14 days to achieve sufficient bulk strength for withstanding polymerization stresses since it is a porous material.
The particle size of Biodentine is 10 µm which enhances it setting by hydration.

The development of tag-like structures along with an interfacial layer called “mineral infiltration zone” by dissemination of carbonate from calcium silicate cement into the intertubular dentin, after the denaturing effect of the highly alkaline cement, is the mechanism of adhesion to the dentin surface
There are no studies available in literature regarding the setting reaction, particle size and mechanism of adhesion of TheraCal PT, hence these characteristics remains unknown.
Following the evaluation of the shear bond strength, the distribution of failure modes for TheraCal PT

Both the study groups showed adhesive failures predominantly which could be attributable to inadequate interfacial bond between the material and dentin since adhesive was not used as speculated by Tohidkhah S et al in their similar study using Biodentine and TheraCal LC in permanent molars.

The quality of bonding is impacted by the presence of a thick smear layer, which, if untreated, limits micromechanical adhesion and blocks material’s chemical adherence. It is possible to remove these smear layers using a combination of chemical, mechanical (ultrasonic) and laser techniques. Due to caustic denaturation of interfacial dentin there will be increase in permeability which in turn is influenced by the alkalinity of Biodentine, according to Kaup et al. However, Biodentine still demonstrated exceptional adaptation to dentin even without conditioning.
TheraCal PT’s clinical applicability could be conjectured as there are no published research on it.

Patients who underwent hernia surgery in the XXX Hospital between March 2018 and March 2022 were retrospectively analyzed. March 11, 2018 - March 11, 2020, pre-pandemic, and March 12, 2020 - March 12, 2022 were categorized as pandemic and were evaluated as one-year periods. All abdominal wall hernia operations performed in the hospital were examined.
A total of 1644 patients underwent hernia operations. Patients

While a decrease was observed in total abdominal hernia surgeries performed during the COVID-19 pandemic compared to the pre-pandemic period, no significant increase was found in emergency abdominal hernia surgeries. Patients with ventral and
As our knowledge and experience of the COVID-19 pandemic and surgery increased, guidelines were published, and surgeries were started again.

The first COVID-19 case in XXX was detected on March 10, 2020, and elective operations were restricted as of March 19. Although some restrictions were lifted after the first wave lost its effect, the cancellation of elective operations (excluding surgical oncology procedures) had to be reinstated in the peak waves of COVID-19. Delays in the timely execution of elective operations and the tendency of the public to avoid going to the hospital have increased emergency admissions.

Abdominal wall hernia surgery is among the most often performed procedures in general surgery. It is thought that postponing elective hernia surgeries will increase emergency presentations of hernias, but different data have been published in the literature.

The statements made at the beginning of the pandemic raised the question of where the hernia-related emergencies went during the COVID-19 pandemic after the number of emergency hernia-related operations did not increase. Data from
This study aimed to evaluate the effect of COVID-19 pandemic on emergency and elective hernia operations in our hospital by comparing it with the pre-pandemic periods.
The patients were divided into groups based on their operation time. The number and type of hernia according to the period are given in
Multicenter studies that compared the pre-COVID-19 and the COVID-19 period showed an overall significant reduction of emergency surgical admissions during the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic.

There was a considerable decrease in the volume of gastrointestinal procedures performed during the initial wave of the pandemic, including elective surgeries, urgency/emergency surgeries, and some cancer surgeries.

In May 2020, the European Hernia Society (EHS) recommendations were published for managing adult patients with hernias during the COVID-19 pandemic. It was emphasized that the recommendations for treating hernia patients during the COVID-19 pandemic would differ according to local opportunities. Hernia surgery is a procedure that can be postponed in most cases. It was stated that during any operation, we should take extra care to minimize the risk of virus spread and lung damage and shorten the hospital stay by adapting our surgical approach to patient, situation, and surgeon variables.

As expected, the COVID-19 pandemic has caused the majority of hernia operations to be postponed or canceled. Nevertheless, Contrary to the general expectation, some publications revealed that emergency hernia repairs did not increase as expected but rather tended to decrease.

The main result of our study showed that our hernia operation numbers declined in the COVID-19 period compared to the previous period. However, no significant increase was observed in the number of emergent hernia surgery. The tendency to treat the patients who applied to the emergency department during the COVID-19 period with conservative methods and their reduction may have caused this situation. The limitations of articles examining the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic on emergency hernia surgery were that they only provide a snapshot of a few months of the pandemic.

Our study covers a broader period before, during, and after COVID-19, whereas most studies take snapshots of a period. As a result, the variation of abdominal hernias over time can be better analyzed.

In this study, however, we discovered that the mean age of patients with an abdominal hernia who underwent surgery during the pandemic period was significantly lower than in other periods. This result could be explained by the fact that elderly patients are advised to stay at home unless there is an emergency, and surgeons make more conservative decisions rather than operating on elderly patients during the pandemic.

However, high morbidity and mortality were reported in the study in which COVID-19 patients with severe respiratory distress who underwent emergency surgery due to hernia and other abdominal conditions were examined. In order to prevent this, the importance of rapid evaluation and treatment by a special surgical team was emphasized.

Therefore, manual reduction came to the fore as a solution for incarcerated hernia patients. A review reports that manual reduction of hernia under analgesia/sedation (Taxis) in the acute inguinal hernia is a helpful technique in COVID-19 times to reduce the need for emergency surgery.

Our research has several limitations. It is a single-center, retrospective research. We do not know the number of patients who underwent taxis in the emergency room and did not undergo surgery and the COVID-19 status of patients who underwent emergency surgery. -A. The medulla oblongata is the main center for integration whose activity is modulated by the hypothalamus and superior centers. The sensory fibers have distant bodies in the nodose ganglia. Efferent fibers comprise essentially two main cells, the pre and the postganglionic neurons. The parasympathetic postganglionic fiber is remarkably short. Its neuron is located in the heart, mainly in the atrial wall and in the ganglionated plexuses (paracardiac fat pads)

-A. The myocardial activity does not depend on the innervation. Unlike the skeletal muscle, that atrophies when denervated, the heart maintains its structure and activity independent on the innervation. However, the autonomic nervous system permanently modulates all cardiac properties, through an intense inhibitory (parasympathetic)

Family planning services have been given importance for decades. For various reasons, sterilization has been the first choice of women and the government. It is feared that while achieving large numbers, the quality may be compromised. There were Public Interest Litigations in Supreme Court about the compromised quality of sterilization services.
To compare the quality of sterilization services before and after interventions and the quality between types of institutions.

This study was carried out in two phases. The first phase included visits to 33 institutions from 13 districts on sterilization operation days. The observed lacunae were communicated to the government, and accordingly, some interventions were executed by the government. In the second phase, we visited 13 institutions from five districts. The investigators were from the Department of Community Medicine,

The findings of this unique multisite study indicate that interventions indeed led to improvements in both Primary Health Centers (PHC) and hospitals, but the extent of improvement was more significant in hospitals.
The program has undergone drastic changes since its inception. The program primarily started for the demographic and
It has been included under NHM. Under the program, the most sought service by the public and the government is a female sterilization operation.

We visited the institutions on the day of operation and interviewed healthcare workers and the beneficiaries. Quality of care generally has three core aspects: the readiness of the structure, delivery of services, and consequences of delivering services.
Our observation tool included all three. Moreover, our scoring system was very rigid. While giving marks on some points, we gave one mark if all three clients

The health workers equate quality actions to that project. After directives from Honorable Supreme Court, District Quality Assurance Committees have been established, and their role has been reduced to reviewing sterilization deaths only. Another function coupled with District Quality Assurance Committee is the review of insurance claims related to deaths, complications, or failures through a sub-committee constituted to manage insurance claims. Rather than a regular committee, the sub-committee called as District Insurance Sub Committee is expected to be familiar. The presence of this committee, although perceived as significantly higher after the intervention, still is sub-optimal. Some studies have assessed the quality of MCH services.
The quality of sterilization services can also be assessed through an audit of case records.

Few cross-sectional studies have assessed the quality of sterilization services. To our knowledge, this is the only before-after study about the quality of sterilization services. The intervention was primarily administrative. We were not able to strictly follow the compliance. Community Health Centers scored higher in both phases, particularly in the operation theatre section than Primary Health Centers. We did not include District Hospital, believing quality is less compromised there. Our results indirectly support our assumption. In Madhya Pradesh, also the District Hospitals, all parameters (except one) were better than CHCs. Contradictorily, secondary data analysis from national-level surveys observed better quality of services in PHC than in the District Hospital. The study observed significant differences in all parameters. This considerable difference is probably due to the vast number of women in that study.
The sections related to overall observations and tools/equipment in operation theatre had higher good proportions than indicators from other sections. -------

Unhealthy diets can lead to malnutrition which encompasses undernutrition, micronutrient deficiencies, overweight and obesity. While there is adequate food production in the United States, many key nutrients are consumed at amounts far below the dietary reference intakes. These nutrients have been labeled as
Other nutrients such as magnesium, folate, vitamin B

Individual food choices and dietary intake recommendations are not enough to overcome these gaps in nutritional intake placing many Americans at risk for chronic diseases that have been associated with nutrient deficiencies.

Fortification is another approach that adds nutrients to a food during processing to increase its nutritional value. A well-known example is the fortification of cereal products with folic acid which has greatly reduced the incidence of neural tube defects in the United States.

Fortification approaches, however, are unlikely to be applied to all nutrients of public health concern. More recently, increased focus has been placed on the need to alter nutrient consumption patterns using sustainable biofortification approaches. Biofortification involves enhancing the nutritional content or bioavailability of nutrients in food through fertilizers or environmental factors, conventional breeding, or genetic engineering. Increasing application of this approach has been centered on improving the nutritional content or composition of animal products. Animal diets have been modified to enhance the composition of meat or animal products (e.g. eggs) by adding components to the diet such as grass, plant oils, fish oils, marine algae, oilseeds fat supplements, amino acids, and protein.

These approaches significantly impact the nutritional content of the food. For example, grass-fed beef has higher vitamin E content, and feeding microalgae to laying hens or broilers will increase the DHA content of the resulting eggs or meat.
Likewise, eggs and chicken are also enriched

Nutritional enhancement of commonly ingested foods may be an economic and sustainable approach to alleviate nutrient deficiencies in the general population, but more studies are required to fully evaluate the bioavailability and possible health benefits to humans ingesting these bioenhanced animal products. As an example, 25-hydroxyvitamin D (25[OH]D), the precursor for the active vitamin D metabolite, has been added to the poultry diet to improve bone health and egg production,
but until recently little attention had been given to the 25(OH)D content of common animal foods,
and only recently, have studies begun evaluating the relative bioavailability of these vitamin D and 25(OH)D enhanced animal products.

Bioavailability of nutrients within foods may differ according to the food matrix, the total amount of nutrient ingested and the composition of the meal consumed along with the fortified food. Fat soluble vitamins are more easily absorbed in lipids, while minerals are known to be well absorbed in acidic environments. When evaluating results on nutrient absorption and utilization attention must also be given to the nutritional status of the study participant as nutrient bioavailability is typically regulated in response to nutritional status. Comparing data across studies is often challenging due to differences in study design, meal composition, study population characteristics, amount of the nutrient ingested, and differences in the timing of sample collections. More data are needed on approaches that can be successfully utilized to identify optimal amounts of bioenhanced nutrients in food and to identify ways to integrate these foods into the food supply to target those that will benefit most from these products.

Biofortification of the food system needs to account the genetic, cultural, and social factors that impact dietary intake and utilization of nutrients to optimize nutrient status while preventing adverse effects that may be associated with extremes of nutrient status.

Higher vitamin E content, for instance, may help prevent oxidation of fatty acids. Lipid oxidation decreases palatability and can lead to discoloration of meat which is detrimental to consumer sales. Reaching a beneficial level of biofortification requires multidisciplinary approaches that integrate precision livestock farming (using automated methods to enhance the health, welfare, production, and environmental impact of livestock farming) and livestock phenomics (systematic acquisition of high dimensional phenotypic data). In addition, the possible environmental impact of producing bioenhanced foods must be further analyzed for this to be a means of sustainable food production.

To test the hypothesis that lymph node yield will vary by pathologists’ assistant (PA) in patients undergoing radical cystectomy (RC) with pelvic lymph node dissection (PLND).

This is a single-institution retrospective review that included patients who underwent a RC with PLND for bladder cancer from 01/01/2007-01/01/2018. Predicted mean lymph node counts were generated using multivariable regression analysis.

In a total of 430 patients who underwent RC with PLND, the median lymph node count (IQR) was 15.0 (11.0-21.0). The frequency of the limits of lymphadenectomy was as follows: external iliac, internal iliac and obturator (true pelvis) (33.3%), true
Lymph node yield after RC varies on several known levels including surgeon, extent of lymphadenectomy, and pathologist. This study found no significant variation in lymph node yield according to PA.
Pelvic lymph node dissection during cystectomy has been used to determine adequate surgical quality and assist in accurately staging patients.
Some reports have described associations between nodal count and oncological outcomes at the time of cystectomy, though this observation is controversial.

Nodal counts at the time of pelvic and abdominal surgeries can vary for several reasons. Known causes for variations in nodal count can include the level of dissection, surgical skill, patient anatomy, gross pathological processing, and pathological interpretation.
Some studies have identified significant intraobserver and interobserver variability among pathologists in nodal identification when evaluating the same sample.
In addition, some studies have revealed that submitting cystectomy samples in their entirety can account for about 40% greater yield in the final lymph node count.
In addition, a relationship between pathological processing and lymph node yield has been identified in colorectal cancer.
However, the relationship between the pathologists’ assistant (PA), who performs the gross processing of lymph nodes, and lymph node yield at the time of RC has not been described.

The association between lymph node positivity and lymph node yield was also investigated using two main methods. First, a Spearman correlation coefficient was used to estimate the association between the number of total lymph nodes and number of total positive lymph nodes. Next, Poisson regression analysis was used to develop a model to estimate the adjusted number of positive lymph nodes for a given lymph node quantity. Covariates in the model included level of lymph node dissection, surgical approach, clinical stage, surgeon, pathologist, PA and year of surgery.

, nodal dissection up to the IMA (versus other nodal levels), cT2+ stage (versus <cT2), neoadjuvant chemotherapy (versus no neoadjuvant chemotherapy), and robotic approach (versus open) were associated with greater lymph node counts (
. Statistical differences remained among surgeons, pathologists, extent of lymph node dissection, and clinical stage (

Stein et al also reported that patients with greater than 15 lymph nodes removed had a 11% greater recurrence-free survival than those with less than 16 lymph nodes removed in a review of 1054 patients who underwent RC with PLND with median follow-up greater than 10 years.

Some recent studies, however have failed to find relationships between nodal count and bladder cancer survival. For instance, in a multicenter, randomized, phase-III trial, Gschwend et al compared extended versus limited lymph node dissection in 401 bladder cancer patients. Extended nodal dissection failed to show superiority in regards to recurrence-free survival, though nodal counts were quite high in both groups (19 in the limited vs 31 in the extended arm).

Because the association of lymph node yield and oncological outcomes is still being investigated, but data exists that suggests a positive relationship, it is important to ensure high quality lymph node dissections during these surgeries, as well as during processing and analysis. Our study found variations in lymph node yield on several levels, but did not investigate the oncological implications of these variations. An ongoing prospective, randomized-trial is SWOG S1011, which aims to compare the disease-free survival in bladder cancer patients undergoing extended versus standard PLND will be helpful in understanding the association between nodal dissection and oncological outcomes.

In contrast, in a multicenter review of 731 patients with bladder cancer who underwent RC with PLND, Capitanio et al determined that 25 lymph nodes removed may be the lowest threshold needed to detect a positive lymph node.

Another study by Konety et al reviewed the Surveillance, Epidemiology and End Results (SEER) registry analyzed the impact of the nodal count on several outcomes in 1923 patients who underwent RC for bladder cancer. The study found that a nodal count of 10-14 nodes was most greatly associated with a survival benefit and advocated for a predetermined minimum number of 10-14 lymph nodes to be a surrogate to measure quality of the lymphadenectomy.

When looking at national guidelines, no ymph node yield is mentioned as an indicator for an adequate dissection. Instead, the AUA guidelines recommend a minimum of a standard PLND (external iliac, internal iliac, obturator nodes) and the NCCN guidelines recommend a minimum of the above, as well as the common iliac nodes.

In our study, the minimum number of lymph nodes required to obtain a positive node was 20 for the entire cohort and 17 in patients with cT2+ disease. With wide variations between various studies regarding the minimum number of lymph nodes needed to constitute a high-quality dissection, it is likely there are unmeasurable variations between institutions on several levels pertaining to lymph node yield.

Mitra et investigated factors associated with nodal count in 2464 patients who underwent extended PLND and identified age, BMI, ASA score, stage, multifocality and positive surgical margin as factors that influence nodal yield.
Another study by Davies et al reported results of a super-extended PLND performed on 26 human cadavers and identified a large range of lymph nodes yielded (10

Some studies have focused on pathological aspects of the evaluation. For instance, Parkash in et al sought to identify reasons for variability in nodal counts in any surgeries by evaluating differences between pathologists. The study included 10 pathologists who counted nodes on 15 slides on two occasions. There was significant variability when the number of nodes exceeded 8 on a given slide and the 95% confidence interval was ±2.6 with a mean nodal count of 5.7. There was also some intraobserver variability observed in the study, as pathologists repeated assessments for some slides and there was some disagreement between pathologists regarding what defined a lymph node and how to count multiple nodes.

Meijer et al looked at variations of nodal dissections in 174 RC specimens by comparing nodal yield by the same surgeons between two different pathology departments. They found that despite similar patient characteristics, the nodal counts were very different between hospitals (28 vs 16,

The study also found variations between urologists in lymph node yield despite standardized dissections. Some studies in the colorectal surgery literature actually looked at the effect of pathological assistants and nodal count. For instance, Ostadi et al reviewed 264 patients who underwent colorectal cancer surgery and identified a wide-range of lymph node yield between pathologists’ assistants (12.6
Our study identified several of the above factors that were associated with differences in yield on multivariable analysis. These included surgeon (

By evaluating the additional packets, there were 39% additional lymph nodes identified. However, none of these additional lymph nodes contained disease, which prompts the question as to whether there is benefit in seeking these additional nodes. Though submitting specimens in their entirety is likely to guarantee increased lymph node yield, there are some drawbacks. First, this process requires more time and resources to be devoted by the pathologists to analyze the additional specimens, Next, this time may have economic implications and contribute to increased healthcare costs. Third, in the study by Gordetsky et al, no metastatic disease was found in the additional lymph nodes sampled, which questions the utility of sampling these nodes. Given these concerns and uncertainty regarding the actual benefit of a higher nodal count and low likelihood of metastatic disease in these additional specimens, it may be difficult to justify modifying institutional standards to analyze RC specimens in their entirety. In our study, we were not able to reliably determine which lymph node packets were submitted in total. Samples are assessed in total at the discretion of pathologist and/or at the request of the surgeon. Thus we could not confirm the clinical significance of such an analysis.

We use our case study to motivate an analytical framework, which leads to a deeper understanding of the events at hand and yields more general hypotheses. In this way, our study of fishing rights can open a path to broader questions of colonial institutional development. While many have argued that colonial institutions influence post-colonial social outcomes, we offer a causal account of how and why such institutions persisted and how they might continue to affect political and economic outcomes.

We argue that a crucial causal variable in the development and persistence of colonial institutions is the strategic ways colonial authorities exercised and expanded their power in colonized societies. Different strategies of consolidating power led to different incentive structures that drove the development of different constellations of political and economic institutions, which in turn molded different typologies of conflict and negotiation among colonial subjects. Our analysis of fishing rights in Bengal illustrates one way this broader process of development played out, in one historical instance.

When Ang II binds to its receptor, the Gα subunit of the G-protein complex dissociates from Gβγ, activating second messenger pathways such as cAMP, PLC, and Rho/Rac. This response leads to increased vascular resistance, cardiac contractility, fluid intake, and sympathetic outflow. However, the signaling can be suppressed through the phosphorylation of the receptor by G-protein receptor kinases, which leads to the binding of the adaptor protein β-arrestin. Administrative restructuring: The first step of the redesign was to create an administrator role to oversee all patient flow operations. As a supplement, we created a triad leadership model, identifying a senior physician and nurse leader as co-leads.

Patient flow governance redesign: Oversight strategy across the care continuum enables the organization to effectively align and improve key processes/workflows and drive clear accountability. The councils represented include Patient Flow Executive Oversight Council, Patient Flow & Capacity Management Advisory Council, Transfer Center Operations Councils, ED Leadership Council, Hospital Operations Council, and Care Progression/LOS (Length of Stay) Council, with dotted-line relationships to ambulatory and postacute operations.
Dashboards: Foundational to the effort was the development of a single-source-of-truth dashboard that displayed the KPIs aligned to the governance model and administrative structure.

Communication: Implemented vests to identify team members and decrease unnecessary crowding in rooms. A time-out process was developed that occurs after all team members arrive so roles can be identified and a standardized process for handoff can occur between primary responders and the medical emergency response team.

Consistent team roles and education: Roles rotated between responding intensive care unit (ICU) charge nurses. In 2019, this stopped. Each responding ICU was assigned a permanent team role and responsibilities were defined. Consistent roles ensured new ICU charge nurses received standardized education and orientation specific to their team role and the new quality processes. This guaranteed expertise and competence.

Quality role: The team leader role is rotated between medical ICU residents. The quality role was designed to coach residents to ensure that American Heart Association and Advanced Cardiovascular Life Support practices are being followed.

Approximately 82% of recalls are now filtered out by the system, with only relevant notifications released and monthly KPI dashboards shared to note status. The quantitative effect was a decrease in staff response from 2.7 to 2.5 days.
Since implementation, the DPP received 59 letters from manufacturers detailing their investigations of defective products.
The FDA recognized Yale New Haven Health for outstanding contributions that resulted in issuing 4 national recalls.

An issue minimized by the manufacturer was persistently reported across our system. With precise data, the FDA elevated it to their specialized division. As a direct result, the manufacturer issued a recall.

Our DPP flagged an alarming product trend, with similar events seen on a cross-check of national databases. Escalation to the manufacturer yielded little response. Strong clinical integration led to a decision to pull the product and notify the FDA. Over 500 of the devices were preemptively removed from clinical sites months before the manufacturer issued a recall.
Our success led to partnering with the FDA and other health systems to share risk mitigation strategies for specific products.
Sharing with staff the local and national impact of their reporting validated their contribution.

Anti-tumour necrosis factor alpha (anti-TNF) treatment accounts for 31% of health care expenditures associated with ulcerative colitis (UC). Withdrawal of anti-TNF in patients with ulcerative colitis (UC) in remission may decrease side effects and infections, while promoting cost containment. Approximately 36% of patients relapse within 12–24 months of anti-TNF withdrawal, but reintroduction of treatment is successful in 80% of patients. We aimed to evaluate the cost-effectiveness of continuation versus withdrawal of anti-TNF in patients with UC in remission.

At 5 years, anti-TNF withdrawal was less costly (-€10,781 per patient), but also slightly less effective (-0.04 QALY per patient) than continued treatment. Continuation of anti-TNF compared to withdrawal costs €300,390/QALY, exceeding the cost-effectiveness threshold. Continued therapy would become cost-effective if the relapse rate following anti-TNF withdrawal was ≥43% higher, or if
Continuation of anti-TNF in UC patients in remission is not cost-effective compared to withdrawal. A stop-and-reintroduction strategy is cost-saving but is slightly
The safety profile of these compounds is generally considered to be good, but side effects including skin reactions,
and severe complications such as serious infections and melanoma or lymphoma do occur.
Moreover, treatment with anti-TNF is currently one of the main drivers of direct health care costs in inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), notwithstanding the recent introduction of biosimilars.

Although anti-TNF is less frequently prescribed in UC than in CD, 25% of the population of IBD patients treated with anti-TNF have UC, and the therapy accounts for 31% of health care expenditures in these patients.

Therefore, withdrawal of anti-TNF in patients with UC in remission could potentially eliminate side effects, infections and cancer risk, and reduce costs for society – provided that the relapse rate is acceptable.
To date, however, no studies have been performed to evaluate the cost-effectiveness of withdrawal of anti-TNF

As the number of patients considered at high risk for relapse increases, the necessary reduction of the relapse rate in patients who withdraw anti-TNF increases. For example, a protocol that identifies 10% or 20% of the patients as high risk, would have to result in a decreased relapse rate of 5% or 10% respectively, to be more cost-effective than withdrawal of anti-TNF in all patients.

Central nervous system (CNS) involvement is present in 70% of hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis (HLH) patients (CNS-HLH) and is associated with a worse prognosis. CNS-HLH is defined by neurological deficits, neuroimaging abnormalities, or positive cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) findings. The CSF cytomorphologic spectrum of CNS-HLH, however, has not been well investigated.
A retrospective review was performed on 64 CSF specimens from
We identified five CSF cytomorphologic patterns in this cohort:
Our study offers a comprehensive view of the cytomorphologic features seen in CSF specimens from HLH patients with or without CNS involvement.

HLH can be further classified as primary (genetic) and secondary (acquired) form. Primary HLH is typically seen in young children with defined genetic abnormalities affecting the lysosomal function of T cells and natural killer cells. Secondary HLH occurs in older individuals as a secondary event of infection or malignancy.
The main histopathologic feature of HLH is the diffuse infiltration of lymphocytes and macrophages into visceral organs, lymph nodes, bone marrow, and central nervous system (CNS).
Studies have demonstrated that 40-70% of both adult and pediatric HLH patients display CNS involvement.

This leads to a broad differential diagnosis, including other more common inflammatory diseases of the brain, such as acute disseminated encephalomyelitis (ADEM), vasculitis, multiple sclerosis, and encephalitis.

So far there is no consensus on the standard treatment of CNS-HLH, but the common regimens are similar to those used in systemic HLH, which include systemic corticosteroid combined with etoposide and cyclosporine A. Intrathecal corticosteroid and methotrexate will be added in patients with poor response or as part of the initial treatment for children. Antithymocyte globulin (ATG) and hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) have also been attempted to treat CNS-HLH.
Therapy must be initiated without inappropriate delay to prevent
The ability to recognize CNS involvement by HLH at early stage is therefore highly critical.

The modality of choice for evaluating CNS involvement in HLH is brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). Multifocal and bilateral abnormalities on T2-weighted imaging in general are the most common finding in both adult and pediatric populations. The finding of symmetric brain involvement on imaging is also helpful in supporting a diagnosis of HLH over other inflammatory entities such as ADEM.
However, a significant proportion of patients have been reported to have normal cerebral MRI scans even when presenting with both neurologic symptoms and abnormal CSF findings.

It has been theorized that this is because the neurologic symptoms are secondary to neurotoxic cytokines secreted by inflammatory cells prior to diffuse infiltration of the brain parenchyma by T lymphocytes and macrophages.

Lumbar puncture is also one of the important diagnostic tools to diagnose CNS involvement by HLH, and is routinely performed on patients if there are no contraindications present. The cytomorphologic spectrum of findings in CSF involved by HLH, however, has not been well investigated. Our study therefore aimed to characterize the cytomorphologic spectrum of CSF involvement by HLH.

While examination for hemophagocytosis is part of the routine workup of CSF in patients with suspected HLH, most literature to date has focused on the laboratory values. One of the larger prospective HLH studies, HLH-94, reported the presence of hemophagocytosis in the CSF of 50 out of 158 pediatric patients (32%),
An older and smaller study by Komp

The frequency of hemophagocytosis found in the CSF in adult HLH has not been reported. In contrast, hemophagocytosis has been described in up to 91% of brain biopsies, most commonly located in the meninges.
Brain biopsy is not a common procedure for diagnosing CNS-HLH, but is occasionally performed in patients that have positive brain imaging findings and yet did not receive a bone marrow biopsy.
However, the invasive nature of a brain biopsy makes it a less than ideal diagnostic modality for CNS-HLH.

Of note, our data suggests that neither WBC counts nor protein concentration alone is a reliable indicator of CNS involvement by CSF, and therefore CSF cytomorphology may offer a more accurate way to diagnose CNS-HLH.
Lipophages, as demonstrated by Sudan black or oil red O staining, in particular are associated with destruction of CNS tissue.
The presence of vacuolated macrophages has been most studied in association with multiple sclerosis, and has been found more frequently in cases of long disease duration.
Vacuolated macrophages in the CSF have also been reported in cases of meningitis,

In children with CNS disease of HLH, the average rate of hemophagocytosis in CSF was 50.7%, including post-treatment specimens. These findings suggest that cytopathologic evaluation of CSF may be particularly useful in identifying CNS involvement in pediatric cases of HLH. CSF cytology in adult HLH patients, in comparison, is of less diagnostic value, given that none of the cases with known CNS involvement had findings of hemophagocytosis. As most adult HLH is believed to be an acquired disease, most commonly due to malignancy or inflammatory/infectious disorders, the variation in findings may be secondary to treatment of previous or co-existing conditions. In addition, while clinical features are similar in children and adults, there is debate as to whether HLH is the same disease between the two populations, and whether different diagnostic criteria are warranted.
The discrepancy in CSF findings may then also represent an underlying difference between adult and pediatric HLH and its clinical course.
Studies have reported abnormal CSFs demonstrating pleocytosis and/or increased protein in

To our knowledge, no studies definitively examining the sensitivity or specificity of any one modality in diagnosing CNS-HLH have been published. Based on our data, CSF cytology appears comparable, and possibly superior, to other modalities for the evaluation of CNS-HLH, especially in pediatric patients.

His bundle pacing (HBP) has gained prominence, but it is still limited by higher capture thresholds at implant compared to RVP and concerns over increasing long term capture thresholds, each potentially resulting in reduced battery longevity.

However, there have not been large studies or randomized controlled trials (RCT) evaluating the long term efficacy and safety of LBBP.

Likewise, measurement of blood iron studies, vitamin D, zinc, prolactin and thyroid profile are not unequivocally related to FPHL (also level of evidence C), for which reasons we do not routinely order these exams. We do order normal preoperative blood tests (hemoglobin/hematocrit, creatinine, platelets, prothrombin and thrombin time) as well as an electrocardiogram, unless there are other clinical issues warranting further preoperative workup. When patients do have signs of androgen excess, a history of PCOS or other hormonal abnormalities, we refer these patients to an endocrinologist. We do not find scalp biopsy to be useful.

Listening-related fatigue can be a significant problem for adults who struggle to hear and understand, particularly adults with hearing loss. However, valid, sensitive, and clinically useful measures for listening-related fatigue do not currently exist. The purpose of this study was to develop and validate a brief clinical tool for measuring listening-related fatigue in adults.

The clinical scale was derived from the 40-item version of the Vanderbilt Fatigue Scale for Adults (VFS-A-40), an existing, reliable, and valid research tool for measuring listening-related fatigue. The study consisted of two phases. Phase 1 (

These data provided us with the opportunity to examine the sensitivity of the VFS-A-10 to variations in listening-related fatigue associated with subjective and objective measures of hearing impairment. VFS-A-10 scores were significantly higher for those with self-reported hearing loss and scores increased systematically as the magnitude of self-reported hearing difficulties increased (at least up to severe losses). In addition, when using the VFS-A-10 we observed a significant, albeit weak, correlation between PTA measures and fatigue ratings. However, consistent with prior research, when we replicated these analyses using generic fatigue and vigor data collected in this study no significant correlations were found. In summary, listening-related fatigue is an important issue for many adults with hearing difficulties. The VFS-A-10 allows for the quick and reliable assessment of listening-related fatigue in this population. We believe the tool will be useful for identifying those individuals most affected by listening-related fatigue and for assessing the effectiveness of any interventions designed to reduce their fatigue. Paraneoplastic neurological syndromes result from an underlying malignant tumor. However, in a significant number of patients underlying primary tumor may remained undetected as conventional CT imaging and onconeural antibodies have a low sensitivity to detect the occult tumor.

Retrospective analysis of findings from FDG PET/CT scans of 143 patients from two PET/CT centres in north India was done and compared to findings of CT scans and onconeural antibody panel of these patients.

Overall 39 (~27%) patients had positive PET/CT findings. Of these, 24 (~17%) patients were proven to have underlying malignant tumor. Among 104 FDG PET/CT negative patients, 6 (~5%) patients were subsequently found to have an underlying malignant tumor on subsequent follow up and work up. Therefore, sensitivity, specificity, PPV, NPV and accuracy of FDG PET/CT for detecting underlying tumor were ~80%, 86.7%, 61.5%, 94.2% and ~ 85.3% respectively. This compares to sensitivity, specificity, PPV, NPV and accuracy of ~60%, 89.8%, 61%, 89.4%, 83.5% for CT and ~43.3%, 97.3%, 81.2%, 86.6% and 86% for onconeural antibodies respectively.

FDG PET/CT should be preferred as initial investigation for detection of underlying malignancy in patients with suspected neurological paraneoplastic syndromes. It can help in early detection of underlying malignancy in a significant number of patients with negative onconeural antibody and conventional CT results. However, a negative FDG PET/CT scan does not always rule out possibility of an underlying malignancy and a follow up is indicated in such clinically suspected PNS cases.
PNS occur in less than one percent of patients with a malignant tumor.
In most of the patients, symptoms of PNS precede detection of underlying tumor.

PNS may affect central nervous system, peripheral nervous system, or neuromuscular junctions and thus present with a complex neurological signs and symptoms and as such their diagnosis is often difficult and delayed.
PNS are thought to be immunologically mediated
resulting from production of certain types of onconeural antibodies.
These antibodies are common to both neural tissue and underlying tumor, and thus mount an immune response, causing irreversible neuronal damage.
In a considerable number of patients, clinical manifestations of PNS may precede the detection of underlying malignant tumor, by an interval ranging from 4-6 months to even up to 4 years.

While PNS may present in virtually all types of malignancies, it is considered to be most commonly associated with small cell lung cancer (SCLC), where as non small cell carcinoma lung, carcinomas of breast, ovary, thymus, testes, and lymphoma are other common malignancies associated with PNS.

Since PNS can present with myriad of neurological symptoms, not specific for any particular syndrome, their diagnosis presents a great dilemma to the neurologist, more so in patients with negative oncooneural antibodies. In September 2019, an international panel of experts (PNS-Care panel) suggested that the criteria for diagnosis of definite PNS solely based on the presence of onconeural antibodies are no longer adequate because of their frequent absence in patients with PNS or even because of their occasional presence in patients without PNS.
Definite treatment of PNS involves tumor specific therapy to remove the tumor or reduced tumor burden and hence underlying antigenic cause of paraneoplastic symptoms.
Therefore detection and localization of underlying malignant tumor at an initial stage is of utmost importance in planning specific treatment of these patients.

Furthermore, occasionally in patients with suspected PNS, underlying primary tumor may be located in a region of body otherwise not clinically suspected and detected incidental to the clinical presentation.
In such cases, FDG PET/CT scan offers advantage of whole body screening in one examination session, and hence improves sensitivity for detection of underlying tumor.
A significant number of incidentally detected FDG PET/CT are found to be malignant on histopathological evaluation.
FDG PET/CT may also be helpful in detection of a metachronous or synchronous tumor in such patients.

While some of these studies conclude that FDG PET/CT should only be performed for patients with well-characterized onconeural antibodies
few others report high sensitivity and specificity of FDG PET/CT for detecting primary tumor in clinically suspected PNS patients without positive or well characterized onconeural antibodies.

In Our study, FDG PET/CT was able to detect an underlying malignant tumor in 12 (~16%) patients, despite their negative onconeural antibody tests, hence showing the usefulness of FDG PET/CT to detect underlying tumor in a significant number of patients with negative onconeural antibody.

Our study showed that FDG PET/CT enabled detection of underlying primary tumor in 9 patients, which earlier been not detected with previous CT imaging. By its virtue of combining a whole body structural and metabolic imaging in a single examination session, FDG PET/CT can enable detection of primary tumor in a significant number of otherwise negative CT studies. Further, it also helped in detection of metachronous or synchronous tumors in 3 patients in the present study

However, such an approach could lead to a delay in diagnosis and appropriate treatment of the underlying malignancy. Our study shows that FDG PET/CT offers an incremental value to both onconeural antibodies and conventional CT in the evaluation of suspected PNS and therefore FDG PET/CT should be initially considered to rule out any underlying malignant tumor.
In our study, follow up and subsequent work up of the initial PET/CT negative cases, identified 6 (~5%) patients with underlying malignant tumor
This could be because our average follow up time period for PET/CT negative patients was 4 years, whereas some tumors can manifest later, even upto 8 years after the onset of PNS.

Hence, a negative PET/CT does not rule out underlying cancer and depending on the clinical presentation and degree of suspicion, follow up with PET/CT scan or other imaging at 6 month intervals may be helpful in detection of previously occult primary tumor even if onconeural antibody panel was also negative.

One of the recognized draw backs of FDG PET/CT is potential for false positives studies for malignant tumor. Altered FDG uptake resulting from physiological variations, or FDG uptake in a variety of infective and inflammatory pathologies
could lead to a false positive rate of 13%.
Present study yielded a false positive rate ~ 10%, associated with a variety of non malignant pathologies

This was a retrospective study based on analysis of patient records resulting from routine clinical practice. Referrals from different clinicians were based on different levels of suspicion. Further, no selection criteria for risk stratification was used. This might have reduced the diagnostic performance of FDG PET/ CT.

Second limitation of the study is in direct head to head comparison of CT scan and FDG PET/CT scans. CT scans were confined to one or maximum of two body regions which were clinically suspected to be the site of primary tumor, while on FDG PET/CT scan, in some patients a primary tumor was detected in a region for which CT had not be performed previously. This may have lead to a relative lower sensitivity of CT for detection for primary in the present study. Furthermore, CT and PET/CT scans had have reported from different government institutes as well as private diagnostic centres. Hence m, minor variations in protocols utilized for the scans and Individual reporting variation do occur care has been taken to review the reports and images and equivocal or suspicious reports were reviewed in consultation with two experienced nuclear medicine specialists.

Though we have used an average follow up period of 4 years, it might still be a limited time frame for ideal follow up with respect to clinical detection of the tumor in initially imaging negative PNS, as in some cases tumor may manifest even upto 8 years after the onset of PNS.
This might have led to reduced reliability of inferences in terms of false negative results

While there is no universal definition for the Metaverse, many define it as
Metaverse is described as a virtual world that exists parallel to the physical world, where users can interact with each other and with digital representations of objects and environments.

Some have even gone so far as to compare it to the Internet, suggesting that it will be just as transformative. The Metaverse has been discussed in the context of everything from social networking to education and to medicine.

discuss the topic of Metaverse and Anesthesia. In their manuscript, they suggest that Meta-Anesthesia is emerging, and we must be ready to incorporate this new construct within the traditional academic approach of patient care, education, and research. While we agree with the content of The Open Mind written by
we would like to provide some additional insights.
Value-based care also focuses on providing the right technology, at the right time, and in the right setting.

When considering the potential use of the Metaverse in healthcare, it is essential to evaluate its potential value in terms of improving patient outcomes and experiences. It is also important to consider the costs associated with implementing and using the technology and to note that the Metaverse is likely not a panacea for all anesthesia challenges. It is a tool that must be used in conjunction with other approaches to improve patient outcomes and experiences. Furthermore, the use of the Metaverse must be carefully evaluated and integrated into existing care processes to ensure that it adds value and does not disrupt care delivery.

The article discusses how the metaverse, which was a hot topic in tech a few years ago, is now facing strong challenges such as slow user adoption due to expensive hardware requirements and glitchy technology. While the hype around the metaverse has receded, and it is unclear when it will reach critical mass, Mark Zuckerberg still sees the metaverse as a long-term focus for Facebook after AI (artificial intelligence), which now seems to be the technology that can deliver results in the near short term.
only mention the Internet of Things (IoT) in passing; however, we submit that the IoT is at the heart of the future of Meta-Anesthesia

In medicine, IoT refers to the use of connected medical devices and sensors that can collect and transmit health data over the internet. MIoT includes (for example) wearable devices that monitor heart rate, blood pressure, and physical activity, smart pill bottles that track medication adherence and send reminders to patients, and much more. As such, in order for the Metaverse to be successful within the context of clinical care, data from various wearables needs to be incorporated into this platform.

also mention the term digital twin in passing when discussing perioperative optimization, but we would like to elaborate on this topic, because just like IoT, digital twin is at the core of any successful model of the anesthesia Metaverse. Within the context of this editorial, a digital twin is the virtual model of a patient, medical device or hospital that can be used for simulation, monitoring, and optimization purposes.

Creating a digital twin can be a complex and challenging process, involving a wide range of technical, organizational, and strategic considerations. Some of the key challenges of creating a digital twin include the need of a vast amount of data, including sensor data, historical data, and other inputs. Collecting and integrating these data can be a significant challenge, particularly when working with patients. Such constraints will determine if using the Metaverse for perioperative optimization of patients has any advantages over the much cheaper approach of telemedicine or simple immersive/virtual reality.

The digital twin patient must also be integrated with other systems and technologies to enable real-time monitoring and control. This can be a significant challenge, particularly when working with legacy systems or complex environments.

is the subject of wearable technology, which is again connected to the issue of the digital twin. Providing information on, for example, heart rate, blood pressure, pulse oximetry, and fitness level, which may be already available from apps such as Health (Apple, Cupertino, CA), will further enhance the construct of the

Those are best done using a tailored approach rather than a generic approach. That is, rather than simply allowing patients to explore the virtual world of the operating room, build an intervention that is based on intake-matrix-output.

First obtain baseline information of the patient that will influence the anxiety of the patient before surgery and then modify the output based on this information. For example, input the information of coping style and trait anxiety of the patient (digital twin) and then modify the output to the patient based on these baseline variables. This reflects, once again, that rather than only focusing on how you deliver an intervention (i.e., Metaverse), you also must focus on the intervention itself.

have provided in their current commentary paper a nice introduction on the topic, the use of Metaverse in the perioperative setting is highly complex and should consider topics such IoT and digital twins. Because of the complexity of such constructs, the timeline for wide adoption of the Metaverse in routine clinical care will take at least five to 10 years. Bill Gates said,

This suggests that while we may overestimate progress in the Metaverse in the short term, we should not underestimate the potential of this platform in the long term. While we agree that the Metaverse has the potential to transform the perioperative delivery of care, it is essential to remember that it must be used in a value-based way. The Metaverse should not be seen as the newest thing in healthcare that we must adopt into the field of anesthesiology, but rather as a tool that must provide added value to patients and healthcare providers.

Department of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery, Faculty of Dentistry, College of Medicine,
Blood transfusion, a critical life-saving procedure is associated with side effects like fever.
To determine the pattern of distribution of transfused blood groups among patients with postoperative fever after major oral surgery.

This is a one-year prospective study of patients that developed fever after major oral and maxillofacial surgery, with or without receiving ABO blood transfusion. Criteria for inclusion include those booked for oral and maxillofacial surgery and without any serious medical conditions. The confounding variables evaluated were divided into clinical and demographic parameters. Both

Of the 108 patients, 23 (21.3%) met the criteria for diagnosis of postoperative fever. Majority (82.6%) of the patients were within 40 years of age. There were 17 males and 6 females with male to female ratio of 2.8: 1. Majority (60.9%, P= 0.021) of the patients having benign and malignant tumors needed blood transfusion. The study showed (78.3%) patients developed fever after blood transfusion while (21.7%) who did not receive transfusion also had postoperative fever. Group O Rhesus D positive blood group was the most common type transfused (P= 0.01), mostly in patients who had malignant lesions, and transfusion was done mainly intra-operatively. Majority (73.9%) of the fever occurred in patients within 24 hours after transfusion, lasting for one day (P= 0.01).

A significant association between the transfusion of blood and the development of postoperative fever, as well as fever occurring more frequently with increased units of blood transfused was noticed. The outcome suggests blood transfusion is a risk factor for postoperative fever in patients after major oral surgery.

working in a developed medical center reported that surgical procedures constitute a major reason for the transfusion of donated blood among hospital patients unlike in underdeveloped centers where it is mainly used to support pregnant women, patients with hematological malignancies, and malnourished children. Hence, blood transfusion is a critical life-saving procedure in surgical practice; however, it is associated with side effects like bacterial and viral infections, febrile non-hemolytic, acute hemolytic transfusion reaction, anaphylaxis,

These side effects occur through different immune-mediated mechanisms which include disruption of the normal delicate balance between pro-and anticoagulation factors that plays a role in venous thrombosis; altered balance between inflammatory factors; antigen-antibody reaction, and release of cytokines from degraded white blood cells in
Hemolytic transfusion reaction could be immediate or delayed. Immediate hemolytic transfusion reaction occurs mainly due to ABO mismatch as individuals have naturally occurring
The common non-infectious causes of postoperative fever include blood transfusion reactions which are usually obvious because they occur during the transfusion of blood.

The fever arising from these reactions is believed to be caused by Cytokines which are gradually released by degraded white blood cells that accumulates in the blood product overtime during storage, these cytokines reset the hypothalamic thermoregulatory center causing a type of fever known as Febrile Non-Hemolytic Transfusion Reaction (FNHTR).
Destruction of incompatible donor white blood cells by the recipients antibodies can also cause this type of fever
Postoperative fever is defined as an increase in body temperature equal to or greater than 38
Postoperative fever presents a common challenge to the surgeon and is frequently seen among surgical patients.
The presence of fever after surgery often results in a series of investigations in search of the etiology; it may also prolong patients
Whereas there are many other blood groups, the ABO blood groups have proved to be the most reliable means of determining the safety of transfused blood and its products.

Consequently, for optimal utilization of blood for transfusion during maxillofacial surgeries, careful evaluation of the pattern of the blood components to be used, the knowledge of the distribution of the ABO blood groups, the condition for its use, the risks arising from it, and the demographic characteristics of the recipients will be necessary.

The aim of this study is to determine pattern of distribution of transfused blood groups among patients with postoperative fever after major oral surgery in the study centre. Data from this study will be helpful in resource-limited settings like that

Besides, literature search could not reveal any information on ABO blood group distribution among oral and maxillofacial surgery patients; hence, this will serve as baseline literature in this specialty.

Data was collected from the patients that presented to the clinic, and accident and emergency unit of the hospital on account of oral and maxillofacial conditions. Those that meet the inclusion criteria were selected and admitted into the Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery ward of the University of Nigeria Teaching Hospital (UNTH) Enugu after being prepared and booked for surgery.
For elective oral and maxillofacial surgery under GA.
Who had no medical condition predisposing to fever.
Who were not on any kind of steroids, NSAIDs or medications that prevent development of fever clinically.
For emergency surgeries on admission less than 2 days.
With medical conditions predisposing to fever e.g. uncontrolled diabetes, hepatitis.
On NSAIDs, steroids, or anti-malaria drugs.
The same thermometer was used for every patient throughout the in-patient course. The thermometer was disinfected after every use with 2%

Many health agencies worldwide have recommended utilizing traditional plants to manage various disorders since they are non-toxic with lesser side effects. Around the world, traditional herbal remedies are used to treat sexual disorders with potent aphrodisiac activity.
These herbs help relax the penile tissue and thus maintain an erection. Also, these herbs help in alleviating psychological elements involved in sexual dysfunction.

Though the utilization of traditional medicine has passed the test of time, it can produce various toxic adverse effects in new and higher dosage forms. Thus, there is the necessity for the evaluation of toxicity of herbal formulations and raw materials.

In assessing and evaluating a test substance’s toxicity, determining the acute toxic effect by the oral route is one of the initial steps. Toxicity analysis is helpful for providing information on acute health hazards likely to arise from human overdoses. Acute toxicity data can serves as a base for the establishment of safe dosing range for repeated administration and can provide basic information on side effects or toxic action of drug substances. Also, the conduct of acute toxicity studies in two rodent species (mice & rats) provides valid safety confirmation.

The repeated dose 90-day oral toxicity study provides evidences of potential health hazards, which can arise from repeated dosing exposure of test drug over a limited period. The data that originates in this type of study provides information on the detrimental effects of the drug on targeted organ tissues, the reversibility of toxic activity and calculations for NOAEL. Our multi-parametric approach has highlighted repercussions of ECM remodeling on cell homing, CF activation and focal adhesion

Although cardiac fibroblast (CF) activation and ECM remodeling prevent the initial rupture of the ventricular wall, they eventually fuel a feed-forward pro-fibrotic mechanism through which cardiac function is progressively impaired, ultimately resulting in heart failure (HF).
The knowledge of in-depth ECM composition, arrangement and remodeling and its effect on cardiac cell function during heart disease is limited.
and its remodeling during cardiac pathologies.

Such studies on ECM pathological remodeling have mostly focused on characterizing the changes in ECM biochemical composition. In this case, tissue decellularization is typically followed by lyophilization and digestion, resulting in loss of the native 3D

Cardiac ECM remodeling has been thoroughly investigated in rodent models through this approach; here, collagen deposition, fibronectin turnover and laminin reduction, as well as impaired ECM compliance have been described.

Despite these advances, how activated CFs contribute to modify ECM structure and stiffness in patients remains largely unknown. Recent studies by our group and others disclosed that the mechanosensitive Yes-associated protein (YAP) is activated after myocardial infarction (MI) in
Interestingly, we recently discovered that YAP is activated by 3D ECM organization
and acts as the main regulator of
YAP transcriptional activity has also been implicated in cancer ECM remodeling,
but its potential role in HF-associated ECM turnover is unknown.

the basis and impact of structural changes due to collagen assembly and alignment in human HF are poorly described.

In this study, we combined SEM, AFM and 3D two-photon microscopy imaging, with the aim of characterizing the alterations occurring in human cardiac ECM biophysical properties at end-stage HF. The samples were obtained from patients diagnosed with DCM or IHD and eligible for LVAD implantation or organ transplantation; the myocardium was treated by a decellularization protocol

that allowed preserving ECM geometry, mechanical properties, and biochemical features. By keeping into consideration that microscale assays might not fully extrapolate to the macroscale ECM heterogeneity of HF, we focused on the myocardium at the

here we analyzed the effective ECM rigidity after decellularization and by multi-mapping strategy to avoid region-specific biases and overcome sample heterogeneity. Therefore, different from well-established models of ischemia in which the scar region is measured, here we show that, HF dECM softens and loses compliance in the absence of the cellular fraction or cellular forces contribution.
SHG is suited to monitor modifications to collagen network

Our study shows a correlation between SHG signal and AFM elastography and found a prevalent fiber orientation (increased anisotropy) in DCM and IHD dECMs, as compared to the more uniform and almost isotropic diffusive tortuosity of healthy dECMs. These anatomic differences contributed to reduce the interconnected porosity and make it a hostile environment, sufficient to hamper cell homing, in the absence of the immune response.

we next obtained CFs lines from DCM patients and performed genome-wide expression profiling and mass spectrometry to identify consistent changes in their gene and protein expression. We reasoned it would be possible by this means to correlate CFs phenotype with their ability to remodel cardiac ECM. The analysis led us to highlight that pathological CFs display altered expression of focal adhesion proteins and ECM-related genes. Indeed, functional analysis confirmed DCM cells more efficiently contract and deform collagen fibers than control cells, and identified Hippo downstream effector YAP as a potent mediator of ECM pathological remodeling. YAP mechanosensitive protein, which is found reactivated in mouse MI
has been already associated with ECM remodeling
and connected to the acquisition of myofibroblast contractile phenotype.

Indeed, by generating CFs reporter cell lines of YAP transcriptional activity through TEAD, we showed DCM cells have sustained YAP expression and transcriptional activity and are more susceptible to differentiate into myofibroblasts. Consistently, YAP ectopic expression in healthy CFs leads them to the acquisition of a superior ability to contract ECM collagen fibers.

Bivalved crustaceans, diverticula of midgut and gonads in carapace. Body generally with 11 free trunk segments, first
Soft-walled carapace partially fused and enlarged in females;

Parasites of ophiuroids living in cysts within genital bursae. Females with bivalved, swollen, usually rounded carapace with dorsal brood chamber. Antennules five-segmented, fourth segment usually with bifid preaxial chin; fifth segment with movable or fixed claw or fused with claw completely. Long, setiform mandibles ending in brush of distal setules. Anterior thoracomeres with various dorsal processes or ridges. Six or five pairs of thoracopods; first thoracopod reduced in size, uniramous or absent. Abdomen five-segmented, furcal rami elongated. Cypridiform males accompanying females with oval, bivalved carapace; thorax without dorsal processes; antennules and mouthparts resembling those of females; six or five pairs of thoracopods, uniramous or with reduced endopods on pairs 2

Mesoparasites of sea-stars, forming cysts. Ovoid or subspherical carapace with short posteroventral or ventral aperture. Antennules minute or absent.
